page.name: overview/requirements
page.summary:
Sparx is completely application server and platform neutral. All of the Sparx's many features are available in any Servlet-compliant application server like WebLogic, Websphere, Tomcat, and Resin. Sparx can work both with or without EJBs. Sparx's main requirement is the Java Developer's Kit (JDK). You can choose the Sun Java SDK, the IBM Java SDK, or any other variety that you prefer, as long as it complies with Java 1.2 or above.
You can obtain Sun's Java SDK from http://java.sun.com.
You can find IBM's Java SDK at http://www.ibm.com/java.

tr.td: Any platform that supports JDK 1.2 or above (e.g. Windows NT/2000/XP, Unix, Linux, Mac).
Any relational or object database that has a JDBC 2.0 driver (e.g. Oracle, Sybase, SQL Server).
Any application server that supports the Java Servlet 2.2 or above specification (Weblogic, Websphere, Resin, Tomcat, etc).
Use any IDE or plain text editor.
Choose from CORBA, EJB, RMI, SOAP, DCOM or other object services.
Use any variety of process models like waterfall, RAD, JAD, XP (Extreme Programming), and other lightweight development processes.

page.section:
Our Developer Kit for evaluation is bundled with several sample applications. The two simpler sample applications, called hello and library, can be run using the bundled (free) HSQL Java database.
One of the larger samples is Cura, a web based project management application for demonstration purposes. If you plan to evaluate Cura you will need to install Oracle (version 8 or newer) on a server and make it available for access by the server that will have the Sparx Developer Kit installed. You can choose to install Oracle on the same server as the Sparx Developer Kit provided it has the resources to handle both an application server and a database server.

You can also install a complete Java integrated development environment (IDE) for developing Sparx applications. Installation of such a development environment is, of course, strictly a personal preference and is completely optional. Sparx does not require nor endorse any particular Java IDE but will work with any IDE or text editor that you might wish to use while developing applications. If you choose to optionally install an IDE, take a look at:
IBM's VisualAge for Java
JBuilder Community Edition
IDEA's IntelliJ
